Effect of calcination temperature and fluorination treatment on NiF2-AlF3 catalysts for dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane to synthesize trifluoroethylene Wenzhi Jia a 1 Yanfeng Chen b 1 Min Liu c 1 Xing Liu d 1 Xinhua Liu e Juanjuan Yuan d Xiaoju Lu a Zhirong Zhu d ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hubei Polytechnic University, 435003, Hubei, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hubei Polytechnic University Hubei 435003 China b Shanghai 3F New Material Co., Ltd, Shanghai, 200092, China Shanghai 3F New Material Co., Ltd Shanghai 200092 China c Department of Chemical Engineering, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, 3052, Australia Department of Chemical Engineering The University of Melbourne Parkville 3052 Australia d School of Chemical Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai, 200092, China School of Chemical Science and Engineering Tongji University Shanghai 200092 China e Dyson School of Design Engineering, Imperial College London, London, SW7 2AZ, UK Dyson School of Design Engineering Imperial College London London SW7 2AZ UK ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract High-performance NiF2-AlF3 fluoride catalysts for the catalytic dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane (CF3CH2F) were prepared by impregnation and fluorination methods. The effect of calcination temperature and vapor-phase fluorination on the properties of NiF2-AlF3 catalysts were investigated by BET, SEM, XRD, UV-DRS, Raman, IR, TG and XPS. By increasing the calcination temperature, the NiO species diffused from the surface into the inside bulk phase of the alumina support and the inverse spinel NiAl2O4 was formed at a calcination temperature up to 600 °C. Vapor-phase fluorination can improve the stability of the catalytic dehydrofluorination. The unfluorinated NiAl2O4 affected the surface area and acidity of NiF2-AlF3 catalyst. The acid sites of catalysts were investigated by py-IR, disclosing that the affinity of Lewis acid sites toward activity of catalysts. In addition, it was found that the weak and medium Lewis acid sites derived from NiF2-AlF3 complex phase are active centers for catalyzing dehydrofluorination of CF3CH2F to trifluoroethylene (CF2=CHF). The highest activity was obtained over a fluorinated catalyst calcined at 500 °C, with a reaction rate of 2.13 mmol min−1 gcat. −1 and a trifluoroethylene selectivity of 99%, highlighting a good prospect for the commercial application. Keywords 1;1;1;2-tetrafluoroethane Trifluoroethylene Dehydrofluorination NiF2-AlF3 catalysts Weak and medium Lewis acid sites 1 Introduction 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane (CF3CH2F, HFC-134a) was considered as a promising alternative to dichlorodifluoromethane (CF2Cl2) due to its zero ozone depletion potential (ODP), and has been widely used in the refrigeration industry [1]. However, according to the Kyoto Protocol, CF3CFH2 with high Global Warming Potential (GWP, > 1300) contributes greatly to the greenhouse effect and should be largely phased out [2]. CF3CFH2 has been replaced eventually by the 2, 3, 3, 3-tetrafluoro-propene (HFO-1234yf). Consequently, the transformation of CF3CFH2 are attracting increasing attention [3]. Numerous methods for the dispose of CF3CFH2 have been reported, such as combustion, photodissociation, water plasmas and catalytic dehydrofluorination [4–7]. Among these methods, the dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 to trifluoroethylene (CF2=CHF) is a promising process due to the high additional value of CF2=CHF for fluoropolymer. The routes to catalytic dehydrofluorination of hydrofluorocarbons are normally used Mg2P2O7 and AlF3, Fe2O3-CdO-Al2O3 and Pd/AlF3 as catalysts [8–12]. Teinz et al found that AlF3 was exclusively selective toward the dehydrohalogenation of 3-chloro-1, 1, 1, 3-tetrafluorobutane, owing to the presence of strong Lewis acid sites [13]. Okazaki et al disclosed that the product distribution was dependent on the acid strength in the CF3CH3 dehydrofluorination over AlF3 catalyst [8]. In addition, Li et al reported that the strength effect of Lewis acid sites of phosphate catalysts, and found that the weak Lewis acid sites were the only active sites for the dehydrofluorination of CF3CH3 to CF2=CH2, while the strong Lewis acid sties resulting in the formation of undesirable coke [9,10]. A previous work reported by our group found that the NiO doped Al2O3 catalyst was a good candidate for the dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 to CF2=CHF [14]. These investigations reveal that the catalytic dehydrofluorination performance significantly depend on the acidity of the applied catalysts. To date, the effect of Lewis acid sites distribution and activity of NiF2-AlF3 catalysts for dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 are not clearly investigated. Herein, NiF2-AlF3 catalysts were prepared and characterized to investigate the relationship between acid sites and catalytic activity for the dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 to CF2CHF. BET, SEM, XRD, UV-DRS, Raman and XPS characterization techniques were employed to disclose the effect of calcination temperature and fluorination on the structure and acidity of the resultant NiF2-AlF3 catalysts. The surface acid sites of the obtained catalysts were characterized by Py-IR. The Raman and TG techniques were used to analyse the carbon deposition during the catalytic process. The evolution of acid active sites of NiF2-AlF3 catalyst correlated to the catalytic performance for dehydrofluorination reaction was also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Al2O3 supports were impregnated with aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and dried at 100 °C overnight. The impregnated supports were calcined at 400, 500, 600 and 700 °C for 3 h in air, respectively. The resultant samples were denoted as NiAlO-4, NiAlO-5, NiAlO-6 and NiAlO-7. The molar ratio of Al/Ni was 9. Prior to use, the prepared NiAlO-x catalysts were subject to the fluorination treatment. The fluorination was carried out in a stainless-steel tubular reactor with a diameter of 3 cm and a length of 40 cm. Specially, 2 g of the prepared NiAlO-x was loaded into the reactor and dried at 260 °C for 1 h. Then, the NiAlO-x was fluorinated at 260 °C and 400 °C for 1 h and 3 h under the mixed gas atmosphere of HF and N2 (HF/N2 = 4), respectively. The finally obtained catalysts were denoted as NiAlF-4, NiAlF-5, NiAlF-6 and NiAlF-7, respectively. 2.2 Characterization Surface areas of the catalysts were determined by the modified BET method from the N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K on an automatic NOVA 2200e apparatus. SEM (HitachiS-4700) was taken on a Hitachi S-4800, catalyst power was directly imbedded in conductive tapes, with an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. XRD patterns were collected with a Focus D8 powder diffractometer (40 kV, Cu-Kα). The pattern for structure refinement was taken in the 2θ range of 10-70° with a step width of 0.02°. Ultraviolet–visible spectra were collected in the range of 200–800 nm using a Varian Cary 5 G UV–vis spectrophotometer working at reflectance diffuse mode (DRS). Raman spectra were collected on a Renishaw RM1000 confocal microscope with an exciting wavelength of 514 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were carried on an RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) with a Mg Kα radiation (hν = 1253.6 eV). The X-ray anode was run at 250 W and the high voltage was kept at 14.0 kV with a detection angle of 54°. The pass energy was fixed at 46.95 or 93.90 eV to ensure sufficient sensitivity. The base pressure of the analyzer chamber was about 5 × 10−8 Pa. Binding energies were calibrated by using the containment carbon (C1s = 284.6 eV). TG experiments were performed using a Netzsch STA 449C instrument. Py-IR was conducted at 200 and 400 °C under a high vacuum. IR spectrum on a self-supported wafer of the sample was collected in the spectral range of 2000–1200 cm−1 with 64 scans. 2.3 Dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 The dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 was carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed metal reactor (15 mm i.d.) and operated in the down flow mode at atmospheric pressure. The reaction temperature was determined with a thermocouple in contact with 2 g catalyst bed. The flow rates of the gas CF3CFH2 and N2 were carefully regulated by mass flow controllers. The molar ratio of N2/CF3CFH2 was 10 with a total flow rate of 22.5 ml min−1 and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 675 h−1. To remove the product of HF, the reaction effluent was passed through an aqueous KOH solution. Then, it was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (HP-5890) using a HP-PLOT/Al2O3 column (I. D. 0.53 mm × 50 m) with an FID detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization Table 1 lists the analytical results of the surface areas and composition of the prepared NiAlO and NiAlF catalysts. The surface area of these catalysts decreased as increasing the calcination temperature. For NiAlF catalyst, its surface area was much smaller than corresponding NiAlO catalyst. For example, the NiAlO-5 catalyst calcined at 500 °C had a surface area of 171 m2 g−1, while only 72 m2 g−1 was obtained on the NiAlF-5 catalyst. The surface element composition of the prepared catalysts was obtained by XPS characterization (Table 1). The amount of carbon was detected by ex-situ XPS measurement. This is because the coverage of a few organics or carbon on the surface of the samples in air. After the fluorination treatment, the surface oxygen concentration of NiAlO decreased sharply and the corresponding fluorine concentration of the resultant NiAlF catalysts significantly increased. NiAlF-5 has much lower surface oxygen concentration (1.52%) than those of NiAlF-4 (20.94%), NiAlF-6 (4.76%) and NiAlF-7 (5.84%), resulting in the highest fluorine concentration. The oxygen removal from the NiAlO catalysts was via the pre-fluorination process: (1) Al2O3 + 6 H F → 2AlF3 + 3H2O (2) NiO + 2 H F → NiF2 + H2O However, NiAlO-4 catalyst presented much lower fluorination degree than other samples under the same fluorination conditions. Such relatively lower fluorination degree is probably due to the surface state NiO, which covered catalyst surface, and result in the formation of thin NiF2 film after fluorination treatment [34,35].The formed NiF2 film restrained the further fluorination process. Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K and pore size distribution of the NiAlO-5 and NiAlF-5 catalysts. The NiAlO-5 show a type IV isotherm with an obvious hysteresis loop, while the NiAlF-5 presents a type II isotherm, according to the IUPAC classification. Type H3 attributed to the NiAlO-5 catalyst, and its pore size is centered on 10 and 15 nm (Fig. 1 inset). The presence of disordered mesopores in NiAlO-5 can be contributed to the gaps between catalyst particles. However, the shape of hysteresis loop is a superposition of H3 and H4 in the NiAlF-5 catalyst [15], and two kinds of pore sizes are centred on 3 and 20 nm. Overall, these results indicate that the fluorination treatment significantly changed the structure and physical properties of the NiAlO precursors. The microstructures of the representative catalysts calcined at 500 °C are shown in Fig. 2 . As seen from Fig. 2a), the NiAlO-5 shows partial slit-shape and the surface porous structure, might be covered with the few disordered and flocculated clusters. Moreover, the morphology properties of NiAlF-5 are shown in Fig. 2b). From Fig. 2b) the surface floccule disappeared and the partial bulk became smooth. The less slit-shape and the surface pores led to decreases in surface area and pore volume of the NiAlF-5 catalyst. Fig. 3 shows XRD patterns of the NiAlO and NiAlF catalysts. Only diffraction peak due to γ-Al2O3 for the individual NiAlO catalyst are detected in Fig. 3a. All of NiAlO precursors only shows the typical γ-Al2O3 diffraction peaks and no characteristic peak of the Ni species were detected, suggesting that small grains of nickel oxide are below detection limit of XRD measurements [16]. Two characteristic peaks due to the formation of AlF3 (PDF#: 44-0231) and NiF2 (PDF#: 76-0605) were observed in the NiAlF catalysts (Fig. 3b). These fluorides were derived from the hydrofluorination of corresponding metal oxide. For the NiAlF-7 catalyst, a main peak at 27° attributed to crystalline NiF2 is weaker than other NiAlF catalysts, which indicates that a relatively lower concentration of the NiF2 presents in the NiAlF catalyst with calcination temperature of 700 °C. UV-DRS results at the band ranging from 200 to 800 nm were recorded for the NiAlO and NiAlF catalysts(Fig. 4 ). Due to the absence of the band gap absorption of the white Al2O3 or AlF3, the band-gap absorption mainly originated from Ni species for both the NiAlO or NiAlF catalysts [17]. As shown in Fig. 4a, the band in the first region of 220–320 nm is attributed to the transition characteristic of the tetrahedral Ni2+ ion in NiO, whereas the absorbance at 345 nm can be related to d-d transitions of bulk NiO [18]. Preda et al. classified NiO in two states (surface and bulk)deposited on highly ordered pyrolitic graphite (HOPG), according to an in situ XPS and ex-situ atomic force microscopy (AFM) studies on the growth of NiO [19]. The band at 345 nm gradually became strong as increasing the calcination temperature, indicating the growth of the bulk NiO species. For the NiAlO-7 catalyst, a broad absorption peak at ca. 510 nm is assigned to υ2 (3A2g→3T1g) transitions of Ni2+ ions in an octahedral symmetry [20]. The absorbance band at 614 nm is assigned to Ni2+ ions in tetrahedral coordination, deriving from the spinel-like structure of the NiAl2O4 [21–23]. The formation of NiAl2O4 was ascribed to the solid-state reaction between NiO and Al2O3 at elevated temperature [24,25]. As can be seen in Fig. 4b, the bands in the first region of 220–340 nm and the weak band at 490 nm are both associated with Ni (II) species (NiF2 and/or NiO). The characteristic bands of NiF2 and NiO are difficult to be distinguished by UV-DRS. Besides, the weak band at 610 nm is attributed to the NiAl2O4 in NiAlF-7 catalyst, indicating that NiAl2O4 was difficult to be fluorinated into NiF2 and AlF3 at high calcination temperature. Raman experiments were conducted to further investigate the Ni species of the NiAlO and NiAlF catalysts. Fig. 5 shows Raman spectra of the NiAlO (a) and NiAlF (b) catalysts. No Raman band is observed for all the NiAlO due to the presence of γ-Al2O3, which agrees well with the previous report [26]. A broad band at 548 cm−1 is attributed to the longitudinal optical (1LO) vibration modes of the surface NiO (dispersed on surface of supports) (Fig. 5a) [24,27]. In-situ Laser Raman of NiO were investigated by Chan and Wachs in detail, it can support that nickel oxide on Al2O3 at room temperature exhibits a Raman band at ∼550 cm-1 [25]. In addition, Zhang et al reported the Raman band at 546 cm-1 was due to the cubic NiO singer-crystals [16], in terms of Raman characterization of the metal-oxide-modified NiO/Al2O3 catalysts for the methanation of CO. Their findings about Raman band of NiO are similar to our results. Furthermore, the intensity of broad Raman peak at 548 cm−1 gradually declined as increasing the calcination temperature, implying that the amount of surface NiO decreased. However, for NiAlO-6 and NiAlO-7 catalysts, the weak broad peak at 805 cm−1 attributed to the TO + lO mode of small bulk NiO [28], became stronger as increasing the calcination temperature. In addition, two weak bands at 375 and 615 cm−1 corresponding to the NiAl2O4 were found in NiAlO-7 [29]. After the fluorination of the NiAlO, γ-Al2O3 was transformed into the crystalline AlF3 (Fig. 3b). However, no characteristic Raman peak was observed for AlF3 (Fig. 5b). The four main bands at 150, 200, 250 and 300 cm−1 are attributed to the rutile-structure antiferromagnets NiF2 [30,31]. As for the NiAlF-7 catalyst, the weak band at 810 nm is attributed to the NiAl2O4 phase, further indicating the difficulty in pre-fluorination of NiAl2O4 species, in agreement with the UV-DRS results (Fig. 4b). Overall, the UV-DRS (Fig. 4a) and Raman spectra (Fig. 5a) collectively confirmed the presence of the surface and bulk phase NiO on the Al2O3 support. There is no UV–vis and Raman band of bulk NiO in the NiAlO-4 catalyst, indicating the whole NiO species occurs in the form of the surface phase. As can be seen from Fig. 5a, the content of surface NiO in the NiAlO-5 catalyst is less than that of the NiAlO-4 catalyst. The bulk phase NiO is the dominant phase for the NiAlO-7 catalyst. The chemical composition and the distribution of Ni and Al species for the NiAlO-5 and the NiAlF catalysts were investigated by means of XPS. Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectra in Ni2p and Al2p region. The phases of Ni and Al species in the NiAlF catalysts were evaluated by deconvolution of the Ni2p3/2, Ni3p and Al2p region spectra, employing the fitting software of XPS peak 4.1. The BE (binding energy) values of corresponding peaks obtained from the deconvolution and the surface element ratio are summarized in Table 2 . As revealed from the analysis of the spectra in Fig. 6a, the Ni 2p3/2 peak of the NiAlO-5 catalyst is resolved into two peaks at 853.4 and 859.3 eV, which were assigned to NiO [32,33]. After fluorination treatment, the environment of Ni species was the characteristic of NiF2, demonstrated by the Ni 2p3/2 peak at a BE of ca. 858.1 eV, and an accompanying shake-up satellite peak at ca. 864.1 eV [34–38]. Whereas, for the NiAlF-4 catalyst, the NiO at a binding energy of ca. 853.2 eV was still observed, with a high oxygen concentration of 20.9% (Table 2). It is proved that the NiAlO-4 was not fully fluorinated, which is in accordance with the above characterization results. For the NiAlF-5 catalyst, only two peaks at 858.2 and 864.1 eV were ascribed to the NiF2 phase, with the highest F concentration (Table 2). For NiAlF-6 and NiAlF-7 catalysts, the BEs at 858.3 and 867.3 eV are both attributed to NiF2, and a BE at 854.4 eV is related to Ni ions in the spinel NiAl2O4 [23,33]. The Al2p and Ni3p spectra are shown in Fig. 6b. For the NiAlO-5, the peaks at around 74.0 eV (Al2p) and 68.1 eV (Ni3p) are attributed to Al2O3 and NiO, respectively [39–41]. For the NiAlF-4 catalyst, the Al2p peak is resolved into two peaks at 74.2 and 77.5 eV. The former peak is assigned to the unfluorinated Al2O3 and the latter is assigned to crystalline AlF3 [42]. The partial fluorination of the NiAlF-4 catalyst is probably due to the presence of large amounts of surface phase NiO, which formed a thin NiF2 film under the pre-fluorination process [34,35], and restrained the further fluorination of Ni and Al oxides. Furthermore, the low BE at 71.6 eV is due to the NiF2 species. In the NiAlF-5 catalyst, the two peaks at 71.2 and 77.9 eV, are due to the characteristic of NiF2 and AlF3, respectively. For the NiAlF-6 and NiAlF-7 catalysts, the AlF3 characteristic peak around 77.5 eV in the Al2p region, and the peak at 71.7 and 69.3 eV are ascribed to NiF2 and NiAl2O4 in the Ni3p region, respectively. Bolt et al investigated interfacial reaction between NiO and Al2O3 to spinel NiAl2O4 by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The Ni3p BE value at 69.1 eV is ascribed to the inverse spinel NiAl2O4, which is very close to our results (69.3 eV) [39]. In addition, the concentration of NiAl2O4 in NiAlF-7 (O: 5.84%) is higher than that of NiAlF-6 (O: 4.76%), in terms of the oxygen atom percentage(Table 1). In summary, UV-DRS (Fig. 4b), Raman (Fig. 5b) spectra and XPS results (Fig. 6b) indicated that the inverse spinel NiAl2O4 still existed in the NiAlF-6 and NiAlF-7 catalysts after fluorination treatment. Besides, it was observed that the appearance of NiAlF-6 and NiAlF-7 catalysts were light blue-green and bright azure blue, respectively, demonstrating the presence of nickel aluminate [43]. The NiAl2O4 crystals in the cubic system and belongs to Fd-3 m space group. It is well-known that inverse spinel NiAl2O4 phase formed under high calcination temperature is the oxidation resistant and nonporous material with a stable structure [16,44]. For the Ni species of NiO/Al2O3 system, spinel NiAl2O4 with the Ni2+ in the form of tetrahedral coordination is difficult to be reduced [33,45,46]. It was revealed by Priecel et al that the spinel NiAl2O4 (Ni(Td)) was difficult to convert into sulfide form after sulfidation [47]. Boukha et al reported that the inverse spinel NiAl2O4 was used as a stable catalyst for methane steam reforming (SRM) under the high reaction temperature [23], with the small surface area of ca. 50 m2 g−1. Therefore, the inverse spinel NiAl2O4 in the NiAlO-7, is difficult to be fluorinated under the fluorination treatment, and has a small surface area. 3.2 Surface acidity Pyridine adsorption is an effective technique to measure the acidity, Lewis- and/or Brönsted-acid of the acidic sites on the NiAlF catalysts. The IR spectroscopic results of the previous reports [48,49], three types of acid sites (weak, medium and strong) existed in the NiAlF catalyst. To further understand the distribution of weak sites and medium acid sites, the catalyst samples of pyridine adsorption at room temperature were outgassed at 100 or 300 °C prior to py-IR tests. Py-IR spectra of the NiAlF catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . It is well known that the wavenumber of the two characteristic bands at 1450 and 1608 cm−1 (ν 19b and ν 8a modes, respectively, of coordinated Py species) account for the Lewis acid sites, and the ν 19b band at 1540 cm−1 is attributed to the Brönsted acid sites [50,51]. Obviously, the presence of Lewis acid sites at ν 19b = 1450 cm−1 on the NiAlF catalysts is observed in Fig. 7 (a) and (b). However, the Brönsted acid sites at ν 19b = 1540 cm−1 cannot be detected by py-IR characterization. Therefore, it can be concluded that the acid site on the surface of the NiAlF catalysts are dominantly the Lewis acidic sites. Besides, the NiAlF-5 catalyst has the strongest IR band at 1450 cm−1 (weak acid sites: 100 °C; medium acid sites: 300 °C), relating to the largest number of weak and medium Lewis acid sites. The species and acid distributions of the NiAlF catalysts are shown in Table 3 . The sequence of weak and medium Lewis acidity of the NiAlF catalysts is as follows: NiAlF-5 > NiAlF-6 > NiAlF-7 > NiAlF-4 (Table 3). The NiAlF-4 catalyst composed of AlF3, NiF2, Al2O3 and NiO, has strong Lewis acid sites (Table 3), which derived from the Al2O3 phase (possessed strong acid sites) [52]. However, the NiAlF-5, -6 and -7 catalysts do not have strong Lewis acid sites. The NiAlF-7 has the lowest total acidic amount(0.521 mmol g−1) among the all fluoride catalysts, while weak and medium (weak&medium) Lewis acidity is higher than those of NiAlF-4 (0.493 mmol g−1). Comparatively, NiAlF-6 and NiAlF-7 catalysts made up of NiF2, AlF3 and NiAl2O4, show the less weak and medium Lewis acid sites than those of NiAlF-5 catalyst. This is probably attributed to the influence of inverse spinel NiAl2O4, which has a very weak acidity. 3.3 Catalytic testing Fig. 8 shows the conversion of CF3CFH2 over NiAlF catalysts and the corresponding selectivity to trifluoroethylene at different temperatures. It can be seen that calcination temperature has a great influence on the catalytic activity. The activity of NiAlF catalyst declined gradually with increasing calcination temperature from 500 to 700 °C. Furthermore, the NiAlF-5 catalyst showed the highest activity among all the NiAlF catalysts due to the high weak and medium active acid sites. For example, CF3CH2F conversion of 32.8% was obtained on the NiAlF-5 catalyst at 480 °C, while conversion of 15.2% was obtained on the NiAlF-4 catalyst. Fig. 9 demonstrates the stability of AlF3, NiAlO-5 and NiAlF-5 catalysts for dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 at 450 °C under the same reaction conditions. The conversion of the unfluorinated NiAlO-5 (metal oxides) declined drastically with time on stream, indicating that it is not stable enough for dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2. This may be the strong acidity (1.426 mmol g−1) of the NiAlO-5 catalyst determined by ammonia adsorption resulted in coking on the catalyst surface. In contrast, the NiAlF-5 catalyst (metal fluorides) possess a high stability. Generally, metal fluorides are more stable than metal oxides, and metal oxide cannot be applied as catalysts and/or supports for reactions in which hydrogen fluoride is involved [53]. The gas-phase fluorination with HF gas is a typical method to activate the catalysts [52], especially for the metal oxide catalyst, because it can improve the rate and stability of catalysts. Interestingly, the conversion of NiAlF-5 catalyst is much higher than that of AlF3 catalyst (Fig. 9), which is attributed to the addition of Ni species. It could be seen that the conversion reduced gradually, and then reached a steady state after 80 h. In addition, statistics summary of the input and output materials were cumulatively calculated during 50 h, and listed in Table 4 . It was found that the loss of input reactant (N2 and CF3CH2F) from 2.948 to 2.867 mol, the materials balance was break up due to the coke transformation of CF3CH2F or CF2=CHF on the catalyst surface. In order to investigate the state of spent catalyst under reaction conditions, XRD were carried out and shown in Fig. S1 (supplementary information). The peaks associated to AlF3 and NiF2 of the NiAlF-5 catalyst increase slowly during the 300 h. The crystalline size of AlF3 and NiF2 increased, suggesting that the NiAlF-5 catalyst might be slightly sintered. Raman spectra and TG curves of the NiAlF-5 catalyst are shown in Fig. S2 (supplementary information). Two intensive broad bands at 1318 and 1593 cm−1 in Raman spectra (Fig. S2 a) are attributed to the A1g and the E2g vibrations of the carbon, respectively [54], indicating that carbon deposited on the surface of the NiAlF-5 catalyst (Fig. S2 a). TG experiments were conducted to further illustrate the coke formation of NiAlF-5 catalyst. An obvious weight loss below 100 ◦C for all the used catalyst was observed in Fig. S2 b, due to the loss of physical adsorption H2O. In addition, a main weight loss was observed around the broad range of 500–590 °C, assigning to the combustion of the deposited carbon on the used catalysts. It is found that the weight loss of the used catalyst increased gradually as reaction time increased, which further confirmed the coke formation on the NiAlF catalyst surface, agrees well with the Raman results (Fig. S2 b). The reproducibility of catalyst is a significant feature for industrial applications from the stand point of decreasing process costs. Therefore, the reproducibility of the NiAlF-5 catalyst in the dehydrofluorination of CF3CH2F was investigated. The spent NiAlF-5 catalyst was regenerated, and reused directly for the next cycle. Fig. S3 (supplementary information) shows the reproducibility of catalytic behaviour. The conversion of CF3CH2F and selectivity to trifluoroethylene were obtained in reaction-regeneration cycles with reaction step at 450 °C. As seen in Fig. S3, the NiAlF-5 catalyst has a good catalytic performance for dehydrofluorination of CF3CH2F to synthesize trifluoroethylene. 3.4 Active sites for dehydrofluorination reaction The relationship between Lewis acidity and catalyst activity for dehydrofluorination reaction is necessary to study. As seen in Table 3, the NiAlF-4 catalyst behaves a lower reaction rate (0.82 mmol min−1 g−1) than the NiAlF-7 catalyst (1.06 mmol min−1 g−1), although it has less weak and medium Lewis acid sites. Moreover, for the NiAlF-5, -6 and -7 catalyst without strong Lewis acid sites, their activities are closely related to weak and medium Lewis acid sites. Fig. 10 shows the relationship between weak and medium Lewis acid sites and reaction rate. It is interesting that the reaction rate for the NiAlF catalysts, increases as the amount of weak and medium Lewis acid sites increasing. The prepared NiAlF-5 catalyst has the excellent catalytic performance for dehydrofluorination of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) compared to the catalysts reported previously. Okazaki and coworkers reported dehydrofluorination of CF3CH3 over various metal fluorides catalysts [8], and found that AlF3 catalyst with Lewis acid sites showed the highest activity, with the conversion of 30%, at a very high temperature of 700 °C. In another group, Li et al. prepared a Mg2P2O4 catalyst and it appears that CF3CH3 conversion became a steady state of 50% over 100 h at 450 °C (W/F = 0.067 g min cm−3, feed gas compositions: CF3CH3 2.0 mol %, H2 15 mol %, and balance N2) [9,10]. However, the initial selectivity of CF2CH2 was only around 75%. In order to compare our normalized rates quantitatively with other reported catalysts, several catalysts were prepared according to the literatures and used for the dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2. Under the same reaction conditions: N2/CF3CH2F = 10, 450 °C, GHSV = 675 h-1, 2.0 g catalysts, the space time yield of the proposed Mg2P2O7, AlF3, Fe2O3-CdO-Al2O3 and Pd/AlF3 catalyst are 0.0153, 0.0571, 0.0326, 0.0617 mol h-1 gcat. -1, respectively. In our work, the NiAlF-5 catalyst possessed the highest space time yield of 0.127 mol h-1 gcat. -1, compared with the reported dehydrofluorination catalysts presently. The NiAlF-5 catalyst can achieve a high reaction rate, which can be attributed to its large weak and medium Lewis acidic amount. Turnover frequency (TOF) of the reaction calculated based on the ratio of rate and weak and medium Lewis acid sites is shown in Table 3. It was found that TOF firstly increased and then decreased with increasing calcination temperature, and the highest TOF is of NiAlF-5 catalyst because of the most weak and medium Lewis acid sites. It was reported by Li et al that weak Lewis acid sites were the only active sites for dehydrofluorination of CF3CH3 to CF2=CH2 [9,10]. Our finding supports the reported conclusion because the activity closely correlates with the weak and medium Lewis acid sites. In our previous works, the relationship between acidity and activity for the dehydrofluorination performance of catalysts were investigated [14,55]. Only the weak Lewis acid was considered as the reaction active site for dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 to CF2CHF. Herein, the acidic distribution of NiAlF catalysts were investigated in detail. It demonstrates that both the weak and medium Lewis acid sites are closely related to the catalytic performance. In conclusion, the weak and medium Lewis acid sites were mainly active centres of catalysts for dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2 to trifluoroethylene. Furthermore, the new finding in this study is that the origin of the weak, medium and strong Lewis acid sites of NiF2-AlF3 catalyst identified. That is, the well Ni and Al oxide species on the catalyst surface could be transformed into isolated NiF2 and AlF3, which act as the weak and medium Lewis acid sites for the dehydrofluorination of CF3CFH2. 4 Conclusion A series of NiAlF catalysts derived from the fluorination of NiO-Al2O3 at different calcination temperatures, were used for the dehydrofluorination of CF3CH2F to synthesize CF2CHF. The highest activity was obtained on a fluorinated catalyst calcined at 500 ◦C, with a reaction rate of 2.13 mmol min−1 gcat. −1 at 450 ◦C. Calcination temperature of the NiAlO catalysts and fluorination treatment have great influence on the structure and acidity of the obtained catalysts. With the increasing calcination temperature, NiO species transformed from the surface into bulk phase, accompanied by the formation of inverse spinel NiAl2O4 over 600 °C. Furthermore, the effect of surface Lewis acid sites on the activity for dehydrofluorination was investigated. It is found that both the weak and medium Lewis acid sites in AlF3-NiF2 complex were the active centres for catalyzing dehydrofluorination of CF3CH2F to trifluoroethylene. coredata.dc:description: High-performance NiF2-AlF3 fluoride catalysts for the catalytic dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane (CF3CH2F) were prepared by impregnation and fluorination methods. The effect of calcination temperature and vapor-phase fluorination on the properties of NiF2-AlF3 catalysts were investigated by BET, SEM, XRD, UV-DRS, Raman, IR, TG and XPS. By increasing the calcination temperature, the NiO species diffused from the surface into the inside bulk phase of the alumina support and the inverse spinel NiAl2O4 was formed at a calcination temperature up to 600 °C. Vapor-phase fluorination can improve the stability of the catalytic dehydrofluorination. The unfluorinated NiAl2O4 affected the surface area and acidity of NiF2-AlF3 catalyst. The acid sites of catalysts were investigated by py-IR, disclosing that the affinity of Lewis acid sites toward activity of catalysts. In addition, it was found that the weak and medium Lewis acid sites derived from NiF2-AlF3 complex phase are active centers for catalyzing dehydrofluorination of CF3CH2F to trifluoroethylene (CF2=CHF). The highest activity was obtained over a fluorinated catalyst calcined at 500 °C, with a reaction rate of 2.13 mmol min−1 gcat. −1 and a trifluoroethylene selectivity of 99%, highlighting a good prospect for the commercial application.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of calcination temperature and fluorination treatment on NiF2-AlF3 catalysts for dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane to synthesize trifluoroethylene

dcterms:subject.$: Weak and medium Lewis acid sites
